It is absolutely, 100% possible to get over your first love. The first few sentences of your post could have been written by me. I'm 20 and was also in a relationship from age 17 that ended last summer. In my case, he treated me horribly toward the end (and during), and that was what I tried to remember. Any time I missed him I would mentally go over the list of things that were bad about him. Are there any things your ex did that hurt you, any negative qualities that he had? It's sort of like when somebody dies, you get love goggles and you only remember the good things about them.
It also sounds like your depression isn't being managed very well. What's your support system like? If you don't feel like your meds are working the way that they should be, it might be worth a quick visit to your doctor. It took me a long time to find the right "cocktail" for me, but once I did, things became a lot easier. Having depression is like being stuck at the bottom of a deep hole, but the right medication could be a ladder for you. You still have to do the work and climb your way out of the hole, but you have that base there that makes it just a little bit easier.
For me, the biggest key to getting over a relationship is distract, distract distract. Remembering that nice Christmas you had together? Oh look, here's a tutorial on how to build a homemade kite. See something that reminds you of him? Here's an article about something you're interested in. I'm not sure if you can make kites at home actually, so maybe don't try that. Even if you don't feel like doing anything, you could watch something interesting on your phone or download a new game to try out. I'm sure if you googled around you could find billions of things to occupy your time. I can also recommend a really awesome breakup playlist.
This has gotten way too long but I feel like I'm talking to my past self. I am much happier now, but it was SUCH a long road to get here. But it is absolutely worth it. My wish for you is that in 5 years you look back on this and remind yourself that you can get through *anything* that comes your way. I'm rooting for you.

WRITING.TEXT:
I've been working in a high end women's clothing store for almost a year now. I started as a general sales associate but I was promoted to the head of the lingerie department about 6 months ago. I have had several other jobs and I've always gotten along well with my coworkers and supervisors so I don't think that my personality factors in.
My boss has been there for about 2 years. During the interview process, we talked for about 15 minutes and then she hired me on the spot, which she told me she's never done before. The first shift that I had, though, her demeanor totally changed. She was short with me and rolled her eyes every time I had a question. Her take on 'training' is basically to throw the employee in the middle of the action and they'll have to figure it out themselves.
The turnover rate for my store is absolutely abysmal; the average length that we employ someone is 5 months. Aside from my boss, I've been here the longest.
Onto the pressing issue, I recently got sick but since my boss dislikes when people call in sick, I stuck it out for a couple shifts and just relied on tea and Buckleys. Last Saturday, though, I was puking uncontrollably so I called in sick and went to the doctor. He gave me some medication for the nausea and told me to stay on bed rest. I turned my sick note in the next shift I had.
Since it's December I've been working a LOT of hours despite being part time (I'm a full time student). I was scheduled to work approx 35 hours a week for the rest of December which was going to be really hard to handle on top of school, but I was managing quite well.
Skip to this morning, I opened the store and went to double check the schedule to see who else I worked with, and almost all of my shifts have been crossed out. I am now working 4 hours a week for the rest of December. My parents pay my rent so I don't have to worry about housing or anything, but I'm still annoyed and confused.
My coworkers are as mad as I am and have said they would back me up if I contact HR, but at this point I kind of just want to quit. I was offered a job a couple of weeks ago that pays almost twice what I make here, but I'm really good at my current job and I get excited to go to work.
This isn't the first instance of my boss screwing her employees over. She has a long history of slacking and spending her entire shift on her phone in the staff room, as well as leaving 4 hours early and telling me to clock her out when her shift is supposed to end. She also manipulates our sales target program and changes other peoples' names to hers so that she looks good in front of her bosses.
I have my letter of resignation typed up and ready to go but I'm on the fence about turning it in. I do really love my job but our HR department has proven ineffective in the past. My boyfriend thinks that I should just quit and report her and hope that they do something, but I feel like that's just the easy way out. Is it?
TL;DR - My boss cut my hours from 35/week to 4/week after I called in sick, despite having a doctor's note. My coworkers and friends think I should report her to HR and see if anything is done, but at this point I kind of just want to be done. Is quitting just the easy way out?

WRITING.TITLE: Old cat hates new cat - what can I do?
WRITING.TEXT:
TL;DR: My newest cat (2 y/o Daisy, female) and my oldest cat (11y/o Max, male) have been growling and hissing at each other ever since I adopted Daisy. I don't know how to make them like each other, or at least tolerate each other.
Hi, all! I recently (as in two days ago) adopted a beautiful 2 year old domestic short haired grey cat, Daisy. She was a little apprehensive on the first day, but I set up a cat lounge in my bedroom complete with her food/water, litter box, hiding places, and toys and she seems to be adjusting to her new life pretty well. She sleeps in my room with me at night and is very snuggly.
Daisy wasn't put in a cage with other cats while she was in the shelter as she had a respiratory infection and some other (resolved) illnesses that the volunteers didn't want spreading to the other animals. She is completely healed now, but as far as I know she hasn't had contact with other cats.
My problem is, I have an 11 year old long haired ginger male named Max, and they do not get along. Max is the most kind and tolerant cat I've ever met; he's been around dogs and cats alike and has never had an issue with them, aside from some hissing if dogs are too close. He's very gentle, and never seems aggressive with other animals, more so scared.
I tried to follow the internet's advice and introduce them gradually, but my parents ruined this by letting them into the same room the first day Daisy was home while I was busy doing something. Daisy growled a little, and they hissed at each other, and then I found out and put her back in my room. Since then, I've let them hang out for 10-15 minutes until one hisses and then I take her back to her cat lounge.
Max hasn't been eating, and he is a very food oriented cat. He even seems disinterested in treats, and he never comes when my mom calls him. In the 11 years we've had him, he has completely bonded to her and barely leaves her side. Now he spends his time chasing Daisy and swatting or hissing at her.
I'm really at a loss, Max seems kind of depressed that there's a new cat in his house, and I don't want Daisy to hurt him, as she swats back. I know I can't go back in time and keep them apart until Daisy is adjusted better and then gradually introduce them, but is there anything I can do as far as damage control? They don't have to be best friends, but it would be good if I could let Daisy out of my room during the day and not worry about her getting stressed out because Max is following her around and bugging her.
Any and all advice is appreciated, thank you for reading!
